body:
I think the idea is that people assume TOR users are usually spammers. True or not, I think the internet WAY overreacts about spam. You don't want it taking over a site, but it's not the fucking end of the world if a bit slips through the cracks. And captchas certainly don't have to be impossible to pass either. When it becomes difficult for actual people to pass the spam filters like on reddit, it's not worth that much protection. I'd take a bit of annoying spam any day over not being able to participate.

I'm not even sure if it's ruqqus doing this intentionally either. It may be something from cloudflare.
body_html:
I think the idea is that people assume TOR users are usually spammers. True or not, I think the internet WAY overreacts about spam. You don't want it taking over a site, but it's not the fucking end of the world if a bit slips through the cracks. And captchas certainly don't have to be impossible to pass either. When it becomes difficult for actual people to pass the spam filters like on reddit, it's not worth that much protection. I'd take a bit of annoying spam any day over not being able to participate.

I'm not even sure if it's ruqqus doing this intentionally either. It may be something from cloudflare.

body: Tor is difficult sometimes because people try to use it for DDOS, but it's possible to open up Tor access. Two approaches I've seen are CAPTCHAs and launching an onion site on a separate server.
body_html: Tor is difficult sometimes because people try to use it for DDOS, but it's possible to open up Tor access. Two approaches I've seen are CAPTCHAs and launching an onion site on a separate server.

body:
CloudFlare has a specific option to allow "legitimate" Tor users.

It's under Network > Onion Routing

Onion Routing allows routing traffic from legitimate users on the Tor network through Cloudflare’s onion services rather than exit nodes, thereby improving privacy of the users and enabling more fine-grained protection.
body_html:
CloudFlare has a specific option to allow "legitimate" Tor users.

It's under Network > Onion Routing

Onion Routing allows routing traffic from legitimate users on the Tor network through Cloudflare’s onion services rather than exit nodes, thereby improving privacy of the users and enabling more fine-grained protection.

body:
Did you know CloudFlare is also a domain registrar?

https://www.cloudflare.com/products/registrar/

They charge at the price they pay, and don't make any money on it.

Currently only allow "transfers" in though, can't register directly yet but if you have a lot of domains it's worth transferring in to them.

They also completely redact your info by default so no need to pay extra for privacy services.
body_html:
Did you know CloudFlare is also a domain registrar?

https://www.cloudflare.com/products/registrar/

They charge at the price they pay, and don't make any money on it.

Currently only allow "transfers" in though, can't register directly yet but if you have a lot of domains it's worth transferring in to them.

They also completely redact your info by default so no need to pay extra for privacy services.

body:
>True or not, I think the internet WAY overreacts about spam. You don't want it taking over a site, but it's not the fucking end of the world if a bit slips through the cracks. 

This, so much this. False negatives are no biggie for something non-infectious, but false positives and the detection method can be, if they piss the users enough. As such trying to eradicate spam *completely* often creates more issues than it solves.

Personal example: the reason I barely use 4chan nowadays is their spam prevention. Fuck that cancerous ReCaptcha.
body_html:
True or not, I think the internet WAY overreacts about spam. You don't want it taking over a site, but it's not the fucking end of the world if a bit slips through the cracks.

This, so much this. False negatives are no biggie for something non-infectious, but false positives and the detection method can be, if they piss the users enough. As such trying to eradicate spam completely often creates more issues than it solves.

Personal example: the reason I barely use 4chan nowadays is their spam prevention. Fuck that cancerous ReCaptcha.

parent.body:
I think the idea is that people assume TOR users are usually spammers. True or not, I think the internet WAY overreacts about spam. You don't want it taking over a site, but it's not the fucking end of the world if a bit slips through the cracks. And captchas certainly don't have to be impossible to pass either. When it becomes difficult for actual people to pass the spam filters like on reddit, it's not worth that much protection. I'd take a bit of annoying spam any day over not being able to participate.

I'm not even sure if it's ruqqus doing this intentionally either. It may be something from cloudflare.
parent.body_html:
I think the idea is that people assume TOR users are usually spammers. True or not, I think the internet WAY overreacts about spam. You don't want it taking over a site, but it's not the fucking end of the world if a bit slips through the cracks. And captchas certainly don't have to be impossible to pass either. When it becomes difficult for actual people to pass the spam filters like on reddit, it's not worth that much protection. I'd take a bit of annoying spam any day over not being able to participate.

I'm not even sure if it's ruqqus doing this intentionally either. It may be something from cloudflare.

body: A non illegal tor website would be fantastic because simply using tor is too big of a technological barrier for most people, meaning we could foster a very unique community without the threat of swarms of non interesting people saturating the site with bullshit
